body.p: ∏ implements name spaces as a language feature. Name spaces provide a way to encapsulate code in a complex, multi-vendor environment. Through judicious use of name spaces, different frameworks can define classes without fear of naming collisions when they are integrated. E.g., both vendor X and vendor Y could define class Customer and use name spaces to disambiguate.
A name space can also define shared variables, which are generally private to its associated classes.

name spacecreateUse the New Name Space tool to create a name space :
Select the parent name space (typically, this should be Smalltalk.* or your application’s name space) in the browser’s class view, and choose Class → New → Namespace.
In the New Name Space dialog, enter a name for the name space. Verify the package and parent name space entries.
Click OK to create the new name space.
name spacenamingName space names and hierarchies should be selected to help avoid collisions. We recommend using a long form of your company name, since it is less likely to be used by someone else.
Cincom provides a web page via which customers can reserve top-level name space names.

name spacemake privateName spaces, classes, and shared variables are defined as either public or private. By default, new name spaces are public and thus exported and available for import by another name space or class.
To make a name space private at creation, check the private checkbox in the New Name Space dialog.
To set an existing name space to private, set its private field to true in the Definition pane.
name spaceimportName space and class definitions can specify the names of bindings — name spaces, classes, or shared variables — to import. Only public bindings can be imported.
To specify imports when creating a name space, enter the bindings in the Imports field of the New Name Space dialog.
To specify imports for an existing name space, list the bindings in the imports: field in the name space definition on the Definition page in a System Browser.
Import declarations may be either specific or general.
A specific import specifies a single public binding name: Graphics.SymbolicPaintConstants.ButtonHilite
A general import specifies all public bindings in a class or name space by appending an * (asterisk) as the final name in a binding reference: Smalltalk.*
As a rule, a general import should make its imports private, as in: private Smalltalk.*

name spaceremoveRemoving a name space that has classes in it removes the classes also.
In a System Browser, select the name space.
Select the Remove... command from the Class menu.
If the name space contains classes, you will be asked to confirm the removal.

name spacerenameWhen you rename a name space, the new name appears automatically in the definition of each class in that category.
In a System Browser, select the name space.
Select the Rename... command from the Class menu.
In the resulting dialog, supply the new name. Type a blank space to cancel the operation.
